Abstract Coffee Leaf Rust, caused by Hemileia vastatrix, is the most important disease of Arabica coffee (Coffea arabica), prompting studies aimed at understanding the genetic basis of this pathogen as well as its complex interaction with the host. In this work, eleven H. vastatrix genes (CH1, CH2, G?-protein, MAP Kinase, AAT1_2, AAT3, INV, HXT1p, MAD1p, Asp_AT and RTP1p) putatively involved in the establishment and maintenance of the biotrophy, were identified and their gene expression profile characterized. The expression profile of chitin deacetylases (CH1 and CH2) and G?-protein revealed that these enzymes are involved in host-pathogen recognition and the establishment of the biotrophy during the early stages of infection. However, up regulation of CH1 in late infection stages in H. vastatrix is unparalleled in other rusts. The MAP kinase gene was only activated after host invasion and not during appressoria formation, unlike its homologues in other fungi, suggesting that this gene could be specifically involved in the establishment of the biotrophy. Amino acid transporters (AAT1_2 and AAT3), Invertase (INV), Hexose transporter (HXT1p) and Manitol desidrogenase (MAD1p) present similar expression profiles to Uromyces fabae, suggesting a fairly conserved process among rust fungi. A strong up regulation of a homolog of the U. fabae rust transferred protein 1 (RTP1p) was found in H. vastatrix in planta structures, suggesting that it may also be involved in the establishment and maintenance of biotrophy. Overall, our results have provided valuable insights at the molecular level to the current understanding of the biotrophic interaction between H. vastatrix – C. arabica. Keywords: Real time quantitative PCR; Hemileia vastatrix; Coffea arabica; Biotrophy; fungal plant pathogen.
1. Introduction Coffee Leaf Rust, caused by Hemileia vastatrix Berk. & Br., is the most important disease of Arabica coffee (Coffea arabica), which represents 75% of the world coffee production (ICO, 2009). Currently, H. vastatrix occurs frequently with high severity in almost all regions worldwide where coffee is grown, leading to serious social and economic problems (Várzea and Marques, 2005). Therefore, studies with the purpose of better understand H. vastatrix and its complex interaction with the host became crucial and have been conducted in Coffee Rusts Research Center (CIFC/IICT) for more than 50 years (Várzea and Marques, 2005). However, despite the development of resistant coffee varieties to rust, little is known at the molecular level about H. vastatrix (Silva et al., 2006; Várzea and Marques,
2005).
H. vastatrix is a biotrophic fungus, living in close contact with its host, and depends on living tissues for growth and reproduction. Its growth begins with the host surface recognition, in which the uredospores recognize chemical and physical properties of the plant surface and germinate, differentiating appressoria over the stomata (Silva et al., 2006). The appressorium forms a penetration hypha that grows into the substomatal chamber. At the advancing tip of the penetration hypha two thick lateral branches are formed (anchor), and differentiate into a haustorial mother cell that gives rise to a haustorium in the stomata subsidiary cells. Further on, the infection process involves heavy tissue colonization and haustoria formation in mesophyl cells, culminating in spore releasing in bouquet- shaped uredinia, formed through the stomata (Rodrigues Jr. et al., 1975; Coutinho et al., 1993; Martins and Moraes, 1996; Silva et al., 1999). At the early stages of this process the plant can recognize the fungal cell wall components and activate the defense mechanisms. To avoid this recognition, the fungus developed several strategies, such as modifying the cell wall surfaces for a compound that cannot be recognized by the plant, allowing host invasion and fungal survival (Gueddari et al., 2002).
Haustoria have been documented as a key in the establishment and maintenance of biotrophy, since they are responsible for the nutrient uptake and information exchange between the host and the pathogen. For this, they must not be recognized as foreign by the host, in order to avoid defense mechanisms, and should be capable of modifying the host metabolism to ensure total access to nutrients (Hahn and Mendgen, 2001; Mendgen et al., 2000; Voegele and Mendgen, 2003; Voegele and Mendgen, 2010). These functions were proved in 1997 (Hahn et al., 1997), when the first haustorium- specific cDNA library was developed for Uromyces fabae, allowing the identification of gene preferentially expressed in haustoria (PIGs). Since then, a number of genes preferentially or exclusively expressed in haustoria have been identified and their encoded products characterized (for revision see Ellis et al. 2007; Voegele and Mendgen, 2010). For example, in U. fabae, genes involved in the synthesis of vitamins (THI1, THI2 and THI3), sugar uptake (HXT1p, INV, BGL1p, GLK1, MAD1 and ARD1p), aminoacid transport (AAT1p, AAT2p and AAT3p) and establishment and maintenance of biotrophic lifestyle (RTP1p) were already identified (Voegele and Mendgen, 2010). However, despite all efforts, there is still a long road towards a better understanding of the full role of haustoria, even in rusts studied in detail as U. fabae. On the other hand it is also crucial to understand the mechanisms developed by the rust at the early stages of the infection process, in order to avoid plant recognition and defenses. The Chitin Deacetylases, G?- protein and MAP Kinase and others proteins, had been related to this process in several pathogenic fungi (Bolker, 1998; Deising et al., 2000; Gueddari et al., 2002; Lev et al., 1999). Despite all the progress made to better understand the establishment and maintenance of the biotrophic lifestyle, additional studies will be required mainly in H. vastatrix where the molecular processes is still poorly investigated.
Therefore, the aiming of this study was the identification and expression analysis of genes described as putatively involved in the establishment and maintenance of the biotrophy along the differentiation and infection process of H. vastatrix, using the Real-time quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) method, described as a golden standard for gene expression analysis (Bustin et al., 2009; Derveaux et al., 2010; Kubista et al., 2006; Wong and Medrano, 2005).
2. Material and Methods
2.1. Fungal and plant material
In vitro growth: germinated uredospores (GU) and appressoria (Ap) were obtained from fresh uredospores of H. vastatrix isolate CIFC 1065 (Race II). For the GU sample, the uredospores were spread in petri dishes containing distilled water and incubated for 18h at 24ºC in darkness. For the Ap sample, the uredospores were inoculated in artificial oil-collodion membranes (Azinheira et al., 2001), sprayed with water and incubated for 24h with 100% humidity at 24ºC. In vivo growth: The Caturra and Matari varieties of C. arabica were inoculated with fresh uredospores of H. vastatrix isolate CIFC 1065 by spreading spores (1 mg per pair of leaves) with a camel hair brush over the lower surface of young coffee leaves. Distilled water was then sprayed on to the inoculated surface and the plants were kept for 24 h in a dark moist chamber (D’Oliveira, 1954). The plants were then maintained under greenhouse conditions. The leaves were collected at different times after inoculation (18h, 24h, 48h, 72h, 7D, 14D and 21D) in order to represent the progression of infection and host tissue colonization. Fungal and plant material were immediately frozen in liquid nitrogen and stored at – 80ºC.
2.2. Light microscope observations of fresh tissues
For each collection time, the germination of spores, appressorium formation or fungal growth in host tissues was evaluated by light microscopy. At 18h the leaf pieces were painted with transparent nail polish on the lower surface, which was allowed to dry and subsequently removed, stained and mounted in cotton blue lactophenol (Silva et al., 2002). Scoring of the germinated uredospores and appressoria formed was performed on a minimum of six microscope fields of 100 uredospores each per experiment. For the remaining time-points, cross sections of infected leaf fragments made with a freezing microtome (CM1850, Leica) were stained and mounted in cotton blue lactophenol (Silva et al., 1999) to evaluate fungal post-penetration stages. Data was recorded from 60 infection sites per experiment. These data were presented as the combined values of two experiments because no significant differences were found between them. Arcsine-transformed percentages and Student and Fisher Least- Significance-Differences tests were used for the statistical analysis.
2.3. Strategies applied to the identification of genes of interest
Genes of interest were selected from the literature, mainly form U. fabae, according to their role in the biotrophic interaction. In this study we analyzed the expression profile of eleven genes putatively involved in the pathogenicity of H. vastatrix to C. arabica, which may be responsible for: i) establishment of the biotrophic lifestyle (Chitin deacetylase 1 and 2); ii) signaling pathway (G?- protein and MAP Kinase); iii) synthesis of protein (Asp_AT); iv) sugar uptake (HXT1p, MAD1p and INV); v) aminoacid transport (AAT1, AAT2 and AAT3); vi) establishment and maintenance of biotrophic interaction (RTP1p). As previously stated, none of these genes were characterized in H. vastatrix, so the first step was to identify and isolate them. To achieve this, we used two different approaches: design of degenerate primers based on homologous genes from other rust fungi followed by cloning and Sanger sequencing (data not sohwn); or specific primer designed based on sequences from 454 transcriptome pyrosequencing recently obtained for H. vastatrix (Talhinhas et al., 2010).
2.4. RT-qPCR primer design and efficiency
Primers were designed using PerlPrimer v1.1.17 (http://perlprimer.sourceforge.net) (Marshall, 2004) with melting temperatures of 60°C, primer lengths 18-24 bp and 50–60% GC content (Table 1). The generated amplicons spanned 75-360 bp with GC content between 45–60%. Exon/intron boundaries were determined by aligning each cDNA sequence with its corresponding genomic sequence. Whenever possible, primers were designed in exon-exon junctions, to avoid amplification of potential
DNA contaminations. As H. vastatrix is unable to grow in the absence of the host, RNA extracted from the infected leaves is a mix of plant and fungal RNA. This implies that primers have to be specific for the fungus and cannot amplify the plant. Additionally, H. vastatrix samples can be infected by Lecanicillium spp., an hyperparasite fungus, which also must not be amplified. To avoid these problems, an in silico method previously developed (Vieira et al., 2010) was applied and the most promising primers were used. The primer efficiency (Table 1) was tested with the LinRegPCR program (Ramakers et al., 2003) which uses a linear regression analysis of fluorescence data from the exponential phase of PCR amplification to determine amplification efficiency (E). We analyzed our fluorescence data for each primer (RT- qPCR details bellow) and obtained E values for each reaction. The arithmetical mean of E values obtained was calculated and the Emean value used in the subsequent analysis (Cikos et al., 2007; Ramakers et al., 2003; Rutledge et al., 2008).
2.5. Total RNA isolation and cDNA synthesis
Total RNA was extracted from frozen samples using the RNeasy Plant Mini kit (Qiagen, Germany), with addition of an in-solution DNase I digestion. Only RNA samples with 260 nm/280 nm wavelength ratio between 1.9 and 2.1 and 260 nm/230 nm wavelength ratio greater than 2.0 before and after DNase I digestion were used for cDNA synthesis. The quality of RNA samples was also assessed by electrophoresis on 1.2% agarose gels. RNA quantity was determined by means of UV-VIS- spectrophotometry (Lambda EZ201, Perkin-Elmer, USA). A control PCR was run on extracted RNA samples to check the absence of genomic DNA with the cytochrome b primers (Table 1). First-strand cDNAs were synthesized from 1 µg of total RNA in 20 µl final volume, using Omniscript RT kit (Qiagen) and oligo(dT)18 primer (MBI Fermentas, Lithuania) following the manufacturer’s instructions. For each sample, a final volume of 500 µl of cDNA was obtained and stored at -20ºC.

2.6. RT-qPCR
The RT-qPCR was performed using an iQ5 real-time thermalcycler (BioRad, USA), using EvaGreen Supermix (BioRad). Each 15 µl reaction comprised 6 µl template, 7.5 µl EvaGreen Supermix, 0.4 µl of each primer (10 µM) and 0.7 µl of sterile distilled water. The reactions were subjected to an initial denaturation step at 95°C during 10 min followed by 45 cycles at 95°C for 15s, 60°C for 20s and 75ºC 15s. A melting curve analysis was performed at the end of the PCR run over the range 60-95°C, increasing the temperature in a stepwise fashion by 0.5°C every 10s. Baseline and quantification cycle (Cq) were automatically determined using the iQ5 Optical System Software. Three negative controls (1-no template; 2- cDNA of plant; 3- cDNA of Lecanicillium spp.) were run to validate the in silico method and ensure that only cDNA of H. vastatrix was amplified. Each PCR reaction was performed in duplicate and the specificity of the amplicons was checked by melting curve analysis and by 3% agarose gel electrophoresis.

The Relative quantification of genes of interest was calculated using the following formula (Pfaffl, 2001):

3. Results and Discussion
3.1 Fungal development during the infection process
The percentage of germinated uredospores and appressoria was evaluated 18h after the inoculation and no significant differences were observed between the two coffee varieties. In Caturra and Matari assays respectively, 90% and 86% of the inoculated uredospores had germinated and, from these, 45% and 50% had successfully differentiated into appressoria. For each collection time (24h, 48h, 72h, 7D, 14D, 21D) the fungal growth inside host tissues was evaluated by light microscopy (Fig. 1). In both coffee varieties, the majority of appressoria gave rise to penetrations, reaching sequencially the stages of penetration hypha, anchor and haustorial mother cell (HMC) with haustoria. From 72h after the inoculation, the infection sites in which the fungus reached the stage of HMC with haustoria were observed in higher frequency and that value significantly
increased until 14D. At this time, the fungus densely colonized the host mesophyl cells, beyond which the entanglement of the intercellular hyphae originated by different infection sites did not allow the quantification of fungal growth stages. These results suggest that regardless of the analyzed hosts, H. vastatrix seems to have a similar development within leaves, allowing, the comparison of the expression profiles obtained for the selected genes between the two hosts.

3.4. Gene expression profiles: establishment of the biotrophy
In order to establish a biotrophic interaction, rusts need to suppress or evade host defense reactions, allowing its survival. As previously stated, the growth of H. vastatrix begins with the host surface recognition, in which the fungus has to recognize chemical and physical properties of the plant surface to begin the host invasion (Silva et al., 2006). On the other hand, the plant can recognize the fungal cell wall components and activate its defense mechanisms, preventing fungal growth (Gueddari et al., 2002). To avert plant recognition, the biotrophic fungus has developed several strategies, some of wich will be addressed in this work, being Chitin deacetylases, G? – Protein, and MAP kinase crucial for this process. The expression profiles of two Chitin deacetylases (CH1 and CH2; Fig. 2A) showed a peak of activation by 24h, reducing thereafter to undetectable levels at 7D in CH2 or between 48h and 7D in CH1, returning to high expression levels at 14 and 21D. These results highlight that the conversion of chitin to chitosan, as well as the increase of chitin deacetylase activity, only begins after the host invasion, coinciding with the pathogen penetration of the plant tissue by 24h (Deising and Siegrist, 1995; Hahn and Mendgen, 2001; Kafetzopoulos et al., 1993; Mendgen et al., 1996).These strategies of avoiding plant recognition and hypha lyses by extracellular plant chitinases enable fungal survival (Deising and Siegrist, 1995; Gueddari et al., 2002; Hahn and Mendgen, 2001; Mendgen et al., 1996). Moreover, previous studies in U. fabae show an increase in enzyme activity during the penetration phases (Deising and Siegrist, 1995; Mendgen et al., 1996) which supports the first peak observed in our results. The expression increase in the advanced stages of leaf infection could be related with the onset of the production of sporogenic hyphae and new uredospores. However, functional studies will be required to better understand this event.
G?–protein showed two peaks of activation, the first during the uredospore germination and the second in the early stages of the infection process (Fig. 2B). During the former stage a similar activation peak has been observed in Colletotrichum trifolii, although, in this case, after the host invasion the amount of transcript decreased to residual levels (Truesdell et al., 2000). In other pathogenic fungi, using different mutants of G?–protein, deletions on this enzyme resulted in loss of virulence and growth defects, such as incorrect appressoria formation (Bolker, 1998; Deising et al., 2000; Li et al., 2007; Yu, 2006). Given the obtained expression profile, our results support the pivotal role of this enzyme in the regulation of several signaling pathways crucial for a correct appressoria formation and for the unfolding of the subsequent infection process. However, the expression increment during the early stages of penetration/haustoria formation process suggests that G?-protein may also be involved in the establishment of the biotrophy.
MAP kinase showed a higher gene expression in the early stages of the in planta colonization (Fig. 2B) decreasing in late stages. In most of the studied fungi, this enzyme is part of a complex signaling pathway regulated by G? protein and has been associated with the appressoria formation and hypha differentiation (Bolker, 1998; Deising et al., 2000; Di Pietro et al., 2001; Lev et al., 1999; Li et al., 2007). However, according to our results, the MAP Kinase under study does not seem to be involved in fungal germination or appressoria formation, but its expression increases during the formation of the first haustoria, suggesting the overlay with the establishment of the biotrophy in the early stages of post-penetration phases. Probably this enzyme is only activated after the host penetration, however functional studies are required.
Taken together, these results suggest that these enzymes are involved in the early stages of fungal growth and host-surface recognition system. In this way, the expression profile obtained for the Chitin

3.5. Gene expression profiles: nutrient uptake
As previously stated, the maintenance of a biotrophic interaction is deeply associated with the role of haustoria, not only in the nutrient uptake but also in the suppression of host defense responses and/or reprogramming the host’s metabolic flow (Voegele and Mendgen, 2010). Several genes, previously described in a haustorial cDNA library of U. fabae, play a key role in the nutrient uptake, both in sugar metabolism and in amino acid transport (Hahn and Mendgen, 2001; O’Connell and Panstruga, 2006; Panstruga, 2003; Voegele, 2006; Voegele and Mendgen, 2003). Currently, three putative amino acid transporters (AAT1p, AAT2p and AAT3p) are identified in U fabae with different amioacid specificities and expression locations (Hahn et al., 1997; Struck et al., 2002; Struck et al., 2004). However, in a cDNA library of H. vastatrix (Talhinhas et al., 2010), only two genes showed homology to those amino acids transporters. The first (AAT1_2) is homologous to U. fabae AAT1p and AAT2p and the second (AAT3) to AAT3p. Besides the in vitro structures, both amino acid transporters (AAT1_2 and AAT3) were only detected in heavily colonized leaf tissues (14D and 21D). The AAT1_2 expression profile was similar to U. fabae, while the AAT2p and AAT1p genes are exclusively/preferentially expressed in the parasitic phase (haustoria) (Hahn et al., 1997; Struck et al., 2002). However, in U. fabae AAT3p is expressed during all growth phases, instead of only on heavily colonized tissues (Struck et al., 2004). It seems that the capacity for amino acid uptake in both rusts is fully induced only during biotrophic growth, although for H. vastatrix it occurs from 14D on while, for U. fabae occurs during the infection process, mainly in the haustoria. Interestingly, in Trichoderma reesei, a gene encoding a putative amino acid transporter was found to be induced by mycelial wall fragments of the host fungus Rhizoctonia solani (Vasseur et al., 1995). Similar to the both rust, a signal from the host organism might induce morphological and physiological events related to parasitic functions. However, the high Cq values registered for AAT3 at 14 and 21D suggest that, if similar or lower levels of expression were occurring in earlier infection stages, then the lower proportion of fungal RNA in the total RNA extracted in such stages would be bellow the sensitivity threshold of RT-qPCR.
The sugar uptake is also closely associated with the fungal nutrition and seems to be limited to the haustoria (Voegele and Mendgen, 2010). Several studies in U. fabae started to provide a more complete view of the enzymes and sugars involved in this process (Voegele and Mendgen, 2010). In this study, we analyzed the gene expression profile of genes homologous to U. fabae described as pivotal to this process: invertase (INV), hexose transporter (HXT1p) and malate dehydrogenase (MAD1p). All these enzymes seem to be related with the use of sucrose (most abundant carbohydrate sources produced by the plant) as a nutrient source for the pathogen (Hahn and Mendgen, 2001; Mendgen et al., 2000; O’Connell and Panstruga, 2006; Panstruga, 2003; Voegele, 2006; Voegele et al., 2001; Voegele and Mendgen, 2003; Voegele and Mendgen, 2010). INV was activated during all the growth phases of H. vastatrix (Fig. 3B), preferentially at the heavily colonized tissues (14 and 21D). Our expression results gave a similar profile to U. fabae, therefore a similar function can be inferred (Voegele et al., 2006). This enzyme is responsible not only for the cleavage of sucrose into D-glucose and D-frutose (sugars, subsequently transferred into the haustoria), but also for an additional sugar supply to intercellular

hypha since the fungal invertases present in the apoplast could limit the export of carbohydrates from the infected tissue via the phloem, conditioning the plant tissue for a conversion from source to sink (Voegele et al., 2006). In this way, the pathogen constantly ensures its nutrient source. HXT1p, putatively responsible for the sugar transport (D-glucose and D-frutose) into the haustoria, was only detectable in late infection phases (14 and 21D) with relevant activation levels. A similar profile was observed in U. fabae, where this gene seems to be almost exclusively expressed in haustoria. The high expression levels are also in accordance with the previous studies since this gene represents 1.2% of haustorial RNA of U. fabae and is among the highest frequencies found in the haustorium-specific cDNA library (Doehlemann et al., 2005; Reifenberger et al., 1997; Voegele et al., 2001). MAD1p was detected in all stages, with a steady increase of expression as the infection progresses, reaching the highest values at the heavily colonized leaf tissue phases (14 and 21D). This enzyme, converts D- frutose to manitol (storage compound, normally used by the fungus not only as a nutrient source but also as a mean to avoid the oxidative stress resulted from the defense reactions) (Clancy and Coffey, 1980; Jennings et al., 1998; Voegele et al., 2005). Additionally, it is responsible for the nutrient mobilization in germinating uredospores, allowing fungal nutrition before the haustoria formation (Voegele et al., 2005). Taken together, these results suggest that the role of these enzymes in nutrient uptake has been a fairly conserved process in the biotrophic fungi considered (U. fabae and H. vastatrix). Intriguingly, this is in spite of a relatively low homology of these proteins between each of these pathogenic species (data not shown).
The expression profile of Aspartate aminotransferase (AspAT) was analyzed due to its relevance in the most basic processes of H. vastatrix. For many species, AspAT belongs to the aminotransferase subgroup and is involved in the transfer of amino groups (Botton and Dell, 1993; Nakai et al., 1999). In H. vastatrix, this enzyme was more expressed in ungerminated and germinated uredospores as compared to appressoria and to the in planta phases (Fig 3C), suggesting that this enzyme is not necessary for the establishment and the maintenance of the biotrophy. Therefore, future functional studies are required to better understand the role of this enzyme in this complex system.
3.5. Gene expression profiles: maintenance of the biotrophy
Rust fungi can suppress host recognition by transferring proteins from haustoria into plant cells. RTP1p, from U. fabae, was the first gene detected in the cytoplasm and nucleus of host cells (Kemen et al., 2005). In H. vastatrix cDNA library, four genes homologous to U. fabae were identified, however we have only selected for expression studies the one with highest homology score. As can be seen in Fig. 4A, the RTP1p seems to be highly expressed in planta (48h-21D after the inoculation) but not in the in vitro phases, which is expected since this gene was detected in the cytoplasm and nucleus of host cells. RTP1 interferes with plant gene expression, but the molecular basis of this interference remains unclear. To understand the exact biochemical function of RTP1p in plant cells, complementary structural and molecular insights from the identified functional core of RTP1p are essential. It is therefore crucial to determine the 3D structure of RTP1p functional domain. Regardless the validation of these specific functions the role of RTP1p in the maintenance of the biotrophy is unquestionable.
The expression patterns of genes putatively involved in the establishment and maintenance of the biotrophic interaction enhance our comprehension on the genetic basis of H. vastatrix and may pave the way for better understanding the complex interaction between H. vastatrix – C. arabica. This will contribute for a more informed deployment of resistant varieties in coffee crops, and thus leading to a more sustainable agriculture in the countries where the coffee is the major source of resources.

Part III
53
Final considerations
The present work intended to give the first steps in unraveling the molecular processes triggered in H.
vastatrix during the host invasion. For this purpose, fungal genes putatively involved in the
establishment and maintenance of the complex biotrophic interaction between C. arabica – H. vastatrix
were identified and their gene expression profile characterized. No such studies had been previously
conducted in H. vastatrix and expression studies by RT-qPCR are also innovative in rust research.
Moreover, it was developed a method to normalize the proportion of fungal cDNA in the total
plant+fungus cDNA pool, since it is impossible to dissociate H. vastatrix from the host during the
biotrophic phase enabling the validation of reference genes for subsequent RT-qPCR studies. The
employment of this strategy for the validation of RT-qPCR fungal reference genes “in host” stills seems
to be a novelty.
Detailed in vitro and in planta studies enabled the selection of specific normalization factors for each of
these experimental conditions, although a global normalization factor (merging in planta and in vitro
assays) was as informative. as the specific factors when analyzing the expression profile of the G?-
protein. Genes involved in signaling, establishment of biotrophy, transport and metabolism were
identified in H. vastatrix showing homology to genes previously identified in other rust fungi. Further,
expression revealed that H. vastatrix shares similar patterns of expression with U. fabae for most of
these genes, although intriguing differences were recorded for a chitin deacetylase, whose up regulation
in late infection stages in H. vastatrix is unparalleled in other rusts. Also, the MAP kinase gene studied
seems to be only activated after the host invasion and not during appressoria formation, unlike its
homologues in other fungi, suggesting that this gene could be specifically involved in the establishment
of the biotrophy. On the contrary, the genes involved in nutrient uptake studied here revealed fairly
conserved profiles between U. fabae and H. vastatrix), in spite of a relatively low homology of these
proteins. A strong up regulation of a homolog of the U. fabae rust transferred protein 1 was found in H.
vastatrix in planta structures, suggesting that it may also be involved in the establishment and
maintenance of biotrophy.
Results obtained in this work suggest that future studies would benefit from the use of techniques
aiming to enrich samples in fungal material, such as the Laser Capture Microdissection, which may
54
enable more accurate quantification of low copy transcripts particularly in samples representing the
early stages of in planta colonization. The results obtained further suggest the usefulness of expanding
of the RT-qPCR approach to address the expression profiles of other genes, based on the literature
concerning other rust fungi and in the recent H. vastatrix EST libraries obtained by 454 pyrosequencing
representing germinated uredospores, appressoria and advanced stages of coffee leaf tissue
colonization. On the other hand, more detailed studies for selected genes can provide important insights
into the coffee-rust interaction, namely functional studies using heterologous gene expression and
histopathological studies focused on immunolocalization of secreted proteins.
